Patch Set 45: Code-Review+2
Change has been successfully merged
Pls use const expr string instead of hardcoding dbus service and paths
Done
Self name can change to SDRsharedptr or SDRptr something ? I think 'Self' is not relevent name here.
Done
Same comment here also. Use const expr string
Done
Best practice is to declare all the variables at the start of the function and use that variable.
Ack
Range based loop can be used here ?
iStrLen is a integer datatype, therefore, range based loop will not be used here.

Hi Ed / Zhikui Ren,

Could you please provide your suggestions for this patch.

Thanks
The name of the device isn't "SDR", presumably this is something like "controller" or "IPMB device"
Done

Why do we need a class here?  I don't see any description of it in your commit message, and no usage of it in this patch.  In general, "Type" is the place to put this information about what kind of device is being controlled, rather than adding a secondary parameter.
"Class" will be used in next patchset, I will explain those details in the commit message.

In terms of configuration, this would be called something like "IPMBDevice"

"SDR" is an implementation detail on the protocol on how we interact with it, and in configuration, isn't important.
Done
Bus is used for noting the i2c bus, not the IPMB channel number.  Ideally we should be matching up the i2c bus number to the channel number here.
Ack
Lots to do here, but starting to take shape.

Please just inline this in the two places it's used.  Ideally the two places it's used would be deduplicated, but I'm ok with not, it's just more clear in code if we do the shifts in the two places they're required, rather than have a global here.
Done
Does this need to be part of your configuration data in entity-manager?  Or is this default good for all ipmb controllers?
This is default for all IPMB controllers.
Done
This parameter doesn't belong in this enum.  It's a mask, and considering it's only used in one place, please just inline the declaration.
Done
Doesn't look used?

This variable is used in the below patchset.
https://gerrit.openbmc-project.xyz/c/openbmc/dbus-sensors/+/52164
Per the comment on line 18, please put all of these indexes into the data structure into a single enum.
Done
Doesn't look used?

This variable is used in the below patchset.
https://gerrit.openbmc-project.xyz/c/openbmc/dbus-sensors/+/52164
This is only used in one spot, please inline.  Also, it's not clear to me what this parameter is doing, so a comment about what it's for might be appropriate.
Done
Same as above, please put all these indexes in a single enum.
Done
Can we come up with some better naming here?  This is a mask, "thres" and Acce" are strange abbreviations that make this difficult to read.
Done
Similar to others, this param is only used in one scope.  Please inline.
Done
Please explicitly default construct these with zeros similar to how we do other places with = 0;  (like you do on line 101.)
Done
it's a little odd that this initializes to 1 valid record.  Shouldn't it be 0?
To match with the sensor record count, validRecordCount initialized to 1 instead of 0.

A comment should be here about what this is indexed on would be helpful.

It's not clear why this is 5;  Would this be better as an unordered_map or std::map, so we're only storing the things that we are using?

Done

I have changed this to std::map, so we can store things which we are using.

first, please make this more complete.  There are more than 4 sensor types supported by both ipmi and dbus, so lets map as many as we can.

Second, these kinds of map lookups are generally better done as linear array lookups, so that they don't malloc.  IE

constexpr std::array<std::pair<std::string_view, uint8_t>>{
   {"temperature", 1},
   ....
}


One linear scan of a small, compile time table is much faster than mallocing a map and sorting it, then using the map result.

In a perfect world, we could also use std::binary_search and avoid the linear cost, but I doubt it's worth the complexity in this case.


Also, this data structure doesn't even look used?

Changed to std::array and since this array is used in another patch, I moved this to the patch where this array is used.

https://gerrit.openbmc-project.xyz/c/openbmc/dbus-sensors/+/52164
These are only used in IpmbSDRSensor for the moment.  I suspect they can be declared in that file.
Done
?  These kinds of headers are not generally encouraged, especially on new files.
Done
nit, extra parens.
Done

I'm fairly sure this isn't what you intended.  This is constructing a new IPMBSDR instance every time this method is called.  I suspect that item needs its lifetime owned somewhere else (so that if the node is deleted, the item can be deleted as well) and this capture done by weak_ptr, like we do other places.
Done

This is not the correct range check.  you index to 2 on line 53, so this needs to be checked that it's at least of size 2 (although I suspect the standard response is larger, and we should check against that).
Done

nit extra parens;

Non-nit, everywhere else in this file you use explicit index names for response fields;  Lets do the same here and follow a similar pattern.
Done
Please unabbreviate this.  abbreviating "reserve" doesn't save many characters, and makes this harder to read.
Done

same as above, as a general rule, unless it's data specific to that request, you don't want to capture by shared_ptr in an async callback.  This leads to situations where the IpmbSDR object owns _itself_, which can be a problem for destruction and memory "leaks".

Please take a look elsewhere in dbus-sensors where we capture by weak_ptr()
Same as above issue is facing here.
Done
Considering these are part of the same reservation ID, please just put them into a uint16_t in this scope, rather than passing them as two parameters.
To get the Sensor data, these reservation ID needs to be passed as send request data as each byte in line 108.
sure.  ok as is.

Please break the content of this lambda out into its own method and call that directly from the lambda here (note, at some point async_method_call will support std::bind_front, which is the ideal here).  In general, this should be done for most async callbacks of any reasonable size.
Done

For each sensor, we need to read a IPMB response 4 times, so that a complete data will be received. Therefore, each time it receives 18 byte and pushed into the getSdrData vector. After whole data is received, it will send to sdrDataCheck() func to process it.
Done
This check doesn't look right to me.  We're comparing the number of SDRs against the size of the structure?  Please look and see if this is what you intended.

This condition is to check whether all the data is received for each sensor, since SDR Type 1 have to receive data 4 times (4*18) to get a complete data. iCnt will check the number of times data received for each sensor. If iCnt is less than 4, it will again call getSDRSensorData() func to receive the remaining data. Once iCnt is 4, then it will move to else part and next sensor will be started to receive all the data.

> This condition is to check whether all the data is received for each sensor, since SDR Type 1 have to receive data 4 times (4*18) to get a complete data.

Not all SDRs are type 1.  Not all records are the same size, and you need to pull all records.  I don't think the logic as you've laid it out will work if there are non-type 1 records in the reply.
Ack

Done

Changed the code by reading all records based on the size of data received.
Please prefer to just return here as it saves scopes for following conditionals.
Return cannot be used, since the data is not received fully.
Done
same here as above.  Not sure what's going on with this logic.

This condition is to check whether all the data is received for each sensor, since SDR Type 1 have to receive data 4 times (4*18) to get a complete data. iCnt will check the number of times data received for each sensor. If iCnt is less than 4, it will again call getSDRSensorData() func to receive the remaining data. Once iCnt is 4, then it will move to else part and next sensor will be started to receive all the data.

Some things to realize:
1. Not all SDRs are type 1 SDRs (although they might be on your system).
2. I believe the IPMI command is allowed to return fewer bytes than requested.
3. SDR type 1 size is variable, dependent on the string at the end.
Ack

Done

Changed the code by reading all records based on the size of data received.
Why 1 here?  Shouldn't it be zero?
Done
no need for an else given that line 155 returns.
Since there is no return in if cond (line 136), else part is needed. If line 136 cond is satisfied, then else part should not be executed.
Done
Some of the logic in this branch (about 3-4 of the operations) is shared with the branch above.  please try to deduplicate if you can.
The value assigned to each variable is different for each condition, therefore, not able to deduplicate the variable.
The value assigned to each variable is different for each condition, therefore, not able to deduplicate the variable.
Lets follow up and see if this is still an issue.

possible nullptr dereference if data.size() == 0

You already have a range check down below, it just needs rearranged.
Done

Considering you're indexing based on the "sdr" enum class, please base this check on that structure, with something like sdr::max.  As written, there are no guarantees that we can't index out of the array if sdr::field is > dataLenType01.
Done
I'm not following what this is for.  Is this just to say the SDR is complete?
yes, it will say which host's SDR sensor is complete.
Please move this up above line 182 and use this variable for your check on that line to make that check more clear.
Done
Done
Why is this a loop?  It looks like it's doing the same operation per character (the variable iLoop isn't used).
Done
Considering we're reading from a binary interface here, this needs some sanity checks to ensure the names are printable ascii characters.
Ack
This function needs a range check.  If this method gets passed in data.size() == 0, it will seg fault.
Done
nit, extra parens.
Done

This is assuming the type of the sensor is linear, which hasn't been checked in this function.  It's fine if you don't support they other types, as they're not common, but you need to at least check for them and explicitly ignore those sensors.
Done

nit: These are pretty complex math expressions with a lot of duplicated data.  can we split up at least the calculation of the B double value and the K2 power value into their own variables to make this easier to read?
Done
Given that we have to pre-calculate the double floats of these above to determine the thresholds, could we store these as two doubles to avoid having to call pow() for every sensor reading?
Done
This looks like an index check, but it should be done explicitly against sensorRecord.size() instead of hardcoding the number.
Done

In terms of code, I'm pretty sure this path of adding to IPMBSensor is not going to go the way you want.  IPMBSensor class represents a SINGLE sensor.  Your new SDR code represents multiple sensors read from a device.  I suspect you're going to need a new class here, especially considering basically none of the IPMBSensor parameters are common with this SDR reader.

Once the dbus signal is received from entity manager, "Bus" number will be found and it will be passed as argument to find the number of sensor count in each host and read all the sensor information for that bus number using IPMB (which is done in IpmbSDRSensor.cpp file).

After all the sensor information is received for all host, createSensors() func will be called. If the "xyz.openbmc_project.Configuration.IPMBDevice" interface is found, based on all the sensor information which is already stored in a map, each sensor will be called under single "for loop". This implementation is submitted in below patchset.
https://gerrit.openbmc-project.xyz/c/openbmc/dbus-sensors/+/52164

In this patchset, only sensor information are read and stored in map for all host.

> After all the sensor information is received for all host,

THat's not how these things generally work.  All hosts might not be available.  Generally we have a wait timer.

Will add waitTimer in the below patchset, once the signal is notified.
https://gerrit.openbmc.org/c/openbmc/dbus-sensors/+/53645
If we are given a bus number, we check the SDR info?  That can't be right.  Do we need another parameer to control this behavior, like "use sdr"

I did not understand the above comment. Could you please clarify this comment.

Like what we need to control in SDR parameter?
I think this is now solved.
Please don't do wildcard reference captures; They have lead to use after free errors in the past.  Please explicitly name your captures as needed.
Done
function does not do what this comment says
Ack
Done

That is actually a bug in your code:
https://gerrit.openbmc-project.xyz/c/openbmc/dbus-sensors/+/52160/14/src/IpmbSensor.cpp#610
 The object is a local variable gets out of scope and destroyed when the function returns
Thanks for your response, I have changed to weak_ptr() now.
This block calls self->xxx each line, Can it be encapsulated into a member function of the class?
Done
This is a success case, right? Is it necessary to log?
It is not necessary, I just want to make sure that all the sensor is read for each host. If this needs to be removed, then I will remove this log in the next patchset.
Done
data.size() return type is not uint8_t, why static_cast<uint8_t> here?

Yes, now working on the recent comments gave by Ed and Zhikui.

This struct looks like it had endian issues, that you've resolved by just declaring any non-trivial structure as std::array.  We shouldn't mix parsing types.  Either:

1. This struct needs to use pragma packed, and handle endian issues properly.
2. We shouldn't rely on reinterpret_cast.  from cppcoreguidelines: "Don’t use reinterpret_cast; A strict version of Avoid casts and prefer named casts."

as a general rule, and because we need to parse this structure into something this code can reasonably process anyway, I suspect this structure needs to just use the base, typesafe versions.

Ack

As a named cast, can I use static_cast instead of reinterpret_cast ?
Static cast would not solve the endian issues.  If it were me, I would make this struct use the c++ types, and do the unpacking in code.
I have used std::bit_cast<> for the structure and it is pragma packed.
I don't think std::bit_cast works around endian issues.

(0xC0 & resp->mTolDataByte) << 2
